explanation:
The correct calculation parses 204050 as 204 (thousand) + 050, forming "two hundred four thousand fifty." The student incorrectly segmented the number as "two million" (2,000,000) + "four thousand" (4,000) + "fifty" (50), totaling 2,004,050. 

The error stems from misattributing the first digit (2) to the millions place instead of the hundred thousands. The student treated the six-digit number as if its leftmost digit occupied a seven-digit number's millions position, creating an erroneous "two million" interpretation. 

This directly aligns with place value confusion but specifically at the hundred thousands/millions level, not the hundreds/thousands mixup listed as a related misconception. The error isn't caused by right-to-left reading or spacing issues but by misjudging the magnitude of the leftmost digit's position.
